messageBody:
I did this just yesterday doing a little spike test with LDAP.
I grabbed some example code, threw in some asserts, and did some
stack dumping (using Log4J, though). It started out something like
(I forget the exact code so forgive psuedo-code comments):

public void testConnectionWithClearTextPassword() {
try {
// misc connection code here -
assertEquals("", ldapContext.getSomething());
// more code here

}
catch (Exception e) {
log.error("Exception : ", e);
}
}

Once I saw what was happening, I discovered what exception was
actually being thrown and turned it into something like:

public void testConnectionWithClearTextPassword() {
try {
// misc connection code here -
// more code here

fail("Should have thrown an exception here");
}
catch (AuthenticationException ae) {
// Should come into here since clear text passwords are
// not allowed.
}
catch (Exception e) {
log.error("Exception : ", e);
fail("Should have thrown an AuthenticationException");
}
}

Anyway...I hope that demonstrates examples of both 'a sign of code
that we don't quite know what it does' and why you'd want to have a
try...catch block in a test.

-Eric

--- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> If what you are hinting at here is -- Why write a dump to the
console and
> not just fail() the test? -- the answer is, it's probably a sign of
> poorly written code, either in the test or in the tested class. A
style
> of catching exceptions like this generally tells me that someone
realizes
> an exceptional case can happen but hasn't figured out how to fix
it...
>
> However, if what you are saying is -- Why have try{}catch{} at all
in the
> tests? -- this is, of course, necessary for checked exceptions in
order
> to compile.
>
> =jason
>

> > Hello
> > I've seen some testXXX() methods written with:

> > try {
> > assertTrue( doSomething() );
> > }
> > catch(Exception e)
> > {
> > e.printStackTrace();
> > }

> > testing for a specific exception or lack of
> > a thrown exception, that you don't need the
> > try/catch.
> > Can you help me understand when/why you'd
> > want to use try/catch in test methods?
